thread.title: Snapshot: FAA study: Air traffic controllers too sleepy + Uber for health care + Columbia House files for bankruptcy
thread.title_full: Snapshot: FAA study: Air traffic controllers too sleepy + Uber for health care + Columbia House files for bankruptcy

author: Carla Caldwell
title: Snapshot: FAA study: Air traffic controllers too sleepy + Uber for health care + Columbia House files for bankruptcy
text:
A new Federal Aviation Administration study reveals sleepy air traffic controllers. Weather Tuesday: Partly cloudy. High: 89. Chance of precipitation is 40 percent. Tuesday night: Mostly clear. Low: 72. Chance of precipitation is 40 percent. Click here for more information from Atlanta Business Chronicle broadcast partner WXIA-TV. Today’s Talkers A new study by the Federal Aviation Administration shows that nearly two in 10 controllers had committed significant errors in the previous year -- such as bringing planes too close together -- and over half attributed the errors to fatigue. Click here to read more in a report by The Associated Press. Filmed Entertainment Inc., the parent company of Columbia House, has filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection and wants to sell off what is left of what was a billion-dollar business, reports The Huffington Post. Click here to read more. Google unveils a surprise restructuring, creating a new parent company called Alphabet Inc. restructures Under the rebranding, Google will retain its best-known businesses, such as search, apps, YouTube and Android, reports BBC.com. Click here to read more. Rogue drones a growing national nuisance. Click here to read more. Startups view to build Uber for health care. Click here to read more. Braves The Braves play the Tampa Bay Rays on Tuesday in Florida. Game time is 7:10 p.m. Click here to view the team’s schedule. Other spots business news Millionaire NFL player and wife set annual budget of $60,000 a year. Lions wide receiver Ryan Broyles signed a contract with more than a million in guaranteed money, but his annual budget reflects one of a much smaller salary. Click here to read more.
